awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Between Shannon and Hamming
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last 70 years, information theory and coding have enabled communication technologies that have had an astounding impact on everyday lives. This is possible due to the match between encoding/decoding strategies and corresponding models of the communication channel. Traditional models fall at two ends of a spectrum. Models which assume that the channel is random, such as those involving channel noise governed by a memoryless stochastic process, take an average-case view of the channel: such models are the basis of Shannon theory. At the other extreme, "Hamming"-like models take a worst-case view of the channel: the noise can be chosen adversarially with respect to the communication scheme. However, for several existing and emerging communication systems, the Shannon/average-case view may be too optimistic, whereas the Hamming/worst-case view may be too pessimistic. This project takes up the challenge of studying models that lie between the Shannon and Hamming extremes. The outcomes of this research will inform the design of codes for a multitude of practical settings where average-case interference models may be too optimistic and worst-case models may be too pessimistic, such as wireless multiple-frame communication systems in vehicular networks (VANETS) or the Internet of Things (IoT).

The common way to view the distinction between average-case and worst-case analysis is operational: it is a difference in error criterion. This project takes a different perspective: the difference is in how the interference can depend on the transmitted codeword. This is modeled by assuming the interference is controlled by a jammer. A dependent jammer corresponds to the Hamming model while an independent one corresponds to that of Shannon. Restricting how jammer interference can depend on the codeword transmitted gives rise to models that lie between those of Shannon and Hamming. The project develops theoretical foundations for the study of communication models in which the jammer acts under varying degrees of uncertainty, and identifies new channel models, code designs, and capacity concepts. The project will develop a unified treatment of channel models that lie between the Shannon and Hamming model and abilities to (a) design optimal rate coding schemes that utilize the limitations posed on the jammer; (b) design secure communication schemes that leverage the jammer's constraints to improve traditional tradeoffs between capacity and security; and (c) inform the design of future practical codes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to formalize models for communication systems in which the noise/interference is partially controlled by an adversary who wishes to stymie reliable communication between the transmitter and receiver. Classical information theory has studied two extremes of this model: the "Shannon model" in which interference is random and independent of what is being transmitted, and the coding theory model (which we call the "Hamming model") in which the interference can be chosen with full knowledge of what is being transmitted. Both models correspond to a scenario where the interference is chosen by a malicious jammer: the Shannon model jammer is "oblivious" and cannot see what is transmitted (see Figure) and the Hamming model jammer is "omniscient" and can see exactly what is transmitted (see Figure). This research examined intermediate scenarios where the jammer has a partial view of what is transmitted (see Primary Figure). For example, the jammer may be able to eavesdrop on a noisy version of what is transmitted (see Figure for causal adversaries), or they may have to decide what action to take in an online manner (see Figure for myopic adversaries). This work unified the analysis of these models: a significant outcome was to identify key components of communication strategies which can take advantage of the jammer's limitations to help guide the design of future communication schemes. In addition to research publications and presentations primarily of interest to specialists, this work also supported the production of a survey/tutorial that highlights connections between the underlying mathematical problem and topics in theoretical computer science, combinatorics, graph theory, and algebra. It also raised connections to other related problems in privacy and security. This work has helped train undergraduate and graduate researchers in information theoretic analyses of adversarial communication models. Overall, this project has advanced the understanding of the theoretical foundations of communication models by interpolating between the two traditional approaches and uncovering connections to research fields beyond traditional information theory.

Images (1 of )
  • An omniscient adversarial model. Alice wishes to send a message m to Bob through a channel controlled by a jammer James through an interference signal s. Bob receives a message y which is a function of the transmitted x and the interference s. James can fully observe the transmitted signal x.
    Anand Sarwate
    Creative Commons
    Anand D Sarwate
    Figure showing a communication model with an omniscient adversary
  • A general adversarial model. Alice wishes to send a message m to Bob through a channel controlled by a jammer James through an interference signal s. Bob receives a message y which is a function of the transmitted x and the interference s. James can choose s based on a partial view of the signal x.
    Anand Sarwate
    Creative Commons
    Anand D Sarwate
    Figure showing the intermediate communication model(s) studied in this proposal
  • A myopic adversarial model. James cannot see the transmitted signal x directly but instead observes a noisy version of it, shown as the signal z. James can use z to choose a harmful interference signal s.
    Anand Sarwate
    Creative Commons
    Anand D Sarwate
    Figure showing a communication model with a myopic adversary
  • A causal adversarial model. James must choose the signal s at time t in an online fashion based only on past and current inputs x_1, x_2, ... x_t.
    Anand Sarwate
    Creative Commons
    Anand D Sarwate
    Figure showing a communication model with a causal adversary
  • An oblivious adversarial model. Alice wishes to send a message m to Bob through a channel controlled by a jammer James through an interference signal s. Bob receives a message y which is a function of the transmitted x and the interference s. James cannot observe the transmitted signal x.
    Anand Sarwate
    Creative Commons
    Anand D Sarwate
    Figure showing a communication model with an oblivious adversary
